text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]M_{2\times 2}[/mathjaxinline] denote the vector space of [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] real matrices, and let [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] be the set of symmetric [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] real matrices. (Recall that a matrix is symmetric if it is its own transpose.)
True or false: [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is a subspace of [mathjaxinline]M_{2\times 2}[/mathjaxinline]. Prove your answer, or come up with a counterexample showing that it is not.

optioninput.options: ('I have proven it','I found a counterexample')

font.p: Let's check the three criteria for being a subspace.

If [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] are both symmetric, then [mathjaxinline](A+B)^ t = A^ t + B^ t = A + B,[/mathjaxinline] so [mathjaxinline]A+B[/mathjaxinline] is symmetric. Hence [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is closed under addition.

If [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is symmetric and [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline] is a scalar, then [mathjaxinline](cA)^ t = cA^ t = cA,[/mathjaxinline] so [mathjaxinline]cA[/mathjaxinline] is symmetric. Hence [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is closed under scalar multiplication.
